Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Eco-friendly Production of Carbon Nanosheets for Ultra High Energy Storage Electrode Application
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is applying a plant-based graphene product as a battery material to increase energy storage density, decrease charging times and extend battery life. The benefit to society is that the plant-based material may facilitate adoption of electric vehicles and reduce the grid storage cost of renewable energy, potentially providing greater energy security. The proposed material's cost-efficient nature will facilitate broader adoption of graphene in other advanced technology areas such as composites, conductive inks, printable electronics, catalysis, sensors, and biomedical devices, thereby pushing nanotechnology frontiers.

This SBIR Phase I project proposes to develop a green sustainable process using an abundant plant material as input and producing extremely high purity graphene with superior physical attributes. This feasibility research will demonstrate that high-quality SP2Hybrid graphene can be manufactured from a plant-based raw material at lower costs than current methods of graphene production and is environmentally sustainable. Current production of graphene, such as liquid/chemical exfoliation, uses starting materials derived from non-renewable resources. The proposed process utilizes an abundant cassava crop as feedstock sold as commodity in the US and overseas. Preliminary samples of SP2Hybrid graphene properties have been validated by third parties to have 4X the surface area (2956 m2/g) and up to 5X (5.0 cm3/g) the pore volume of current solutions, offering better performance as an electrode material in batteries and supercapacitors.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
SurgePower Materials has successfully produced high quality and high purity graphene from plant-based feedstock in this feasibility research by significantly de-risking the production process of graphene from ~1 g per day to minimum of 500 g per day. This feasibility research established that high purity carbon nanosheets, graphene can be cost effectively manufactured from

 plant-based raw materials such as cassava plant. The impact of this technology changes the approach of making carbon nanosheets primarily from crude oil product and derivatives to a renewable agricultural feedstock and argument to the body of knowledge on the science and technology of materials synthesis and manufacturing.

 The optimum processing conditions for producing high quality graphene were determined empirically by varying the ratio of plant feed to catalyst as well as thermodynamics conditions of the process such as temperature, pressure, and volume of feed. SurgePower utilized a combination of batch reactors and continuous rotary reactors to increase the throughput of the plant-based graphene from 1 g per day to at least 500 g per day.  The resulting plant-based graphene acquired a nitrogen gas absorption property exceeding 2956 m2/g and 5.1 cm3/g for surface area and pore volume, respectively.

The plant-based graphene was successfully evaluated as a conductive additive in high power lithium-ion batteries by third party. The results obtained from fabrication of coin anode half-cell level testing as conductive additive in high power cells showed no noticeable difference between plant-based graphene and baseline anode conductive additive when cycled to 50 cycles at a charge rate of 0.5C and discharged at 1C.  The anode baseline conductive additive was ~5um expanded graphite powder. This results clearly showed that cost-effective plant-based graphene offers that same performance as a new generation high power conductive additive (expensive expanded graphite) in high power Li-ion batteries.

 In another set of research, the plant-based graphene was utilized as anode active material in single layer pouch Li-ion batteries. The test revealed that plant-based graphene anode cell charges in few minutes instead of hours, 5X (1904 mAh/g at 0.1 C) increase in capacity over standard graphite anode (372 mAh/g). Although, the initial energy density of the plant-based graphene cell remained high even exceeding 9X of standard active graphite material, the initial coulombic efficiency was relatively low. Future cell development work will focus of increasing initial coulombic efficiency and moving to 9Ah double layer pouch cells.

 Adoption of our cost-effective and high quality plant-based graphene for use as electrode material for energy storage devices would immensely reduce charging time, while increasing usage time. This lower cost electrode material will facilitate adoption of high performing electric vehicles.  The cost-efficient and eco-friendly nature will also facilitate adoption of graphene in other advanced technology areas such as composites, conductive inks, printable electronics, catalysis, sensors, and biomedical devices to push nanotechnology frontiers. Although the scope of this research was rooted in materials science and engineering, the impact of this platform technology is Multi-disciplinary. The results from this feasibility study has the potential to transform many industries including but not limited to Agricultural, Automotive, Aerospace, Medical Devices and Protective Equipment, Water Filtration, and Energy Storage.  The technology will bring our society one step closer to a cleaner environment, cleaner energy, green product, and create new jobs.
